strings.Value: "The statue was ancient, and easy to break. Don't try to see hidden signs where there aren't any."
[Leave] "Stop whining. Let's go, we still have a lot to do."
"It was just an old statue. What Torag has to do with it?"
"You confuse the reason with the consequence. Torag's worshippers left this place. Their faith doesn't empower Torag any more, so he has no need to protect this fortress."
"You're only half right. Sure, you can't place your trust in Torag... but you can't trust any of the others, either! They're all the same!"
"Torag never abandons his children. They left this place, and he followed."
"You've confused the god with the sculpture depicting him," {n}Ekun notes calmly, but Harrim doesn't hear him or just doesn't care.{/n}

"You're wrong, {name}. It's not just any statue. It's a symbol. Faith feeds the gods, just like food nourishes our mortal bodies. And the symbols of faith are the channels through which gods communicate with faithful." {n}He grimly looks at the pedestal, where the statue used to stand, but only the stone of Torag's feet remains now.{/n} "This symbol is destroyed. Therefore {g|Torag}Torag{/g} is weak, {name}. If he could protect this place, he wouldn't allow such desolation to happen."

"You're blind. How could this statue possibly be destroyed, if {g|Torag}Torag{/g} was protecting this place? How could dwarves perish here if Torag cared about them?" {n}Harrim presses his lips together.{/n} "No, {name}. This whole place is an anthem for oblivion's victory over weakness. The victory {g|Groetus}Groetus{/g} won over Torag."

{n}Harrim opens his mouth to object, but apparently can't find any good arguments. Finally, he gives up on you.{/n} "You're so blind, {name}," {n}he says, just to fill the silence, and turns away.{/n}
{n}The dwarf turns away from the statue and stalks behind you, staring at the floor.{/n}
{n}You throw a glance towards Ekun, expecting him to stand up for {g|Torag}Torag{/g}, but the ranger just shrugs instead.{/n} "No sense in over-persuading," {n}he says, looking at Harrim.{/n}
"You're weak, {g|Torag}Torag{/g}. Weak and pathetic. How could you, the God of all dwarves, the Great Creator, be knocked down by some meager troll?"
"Also, how can the dwarves put their trust in you, you traitor god? How can you protect your people if you're incapable of defending even yourself?"
"Gods are not pathetic. Those who grovel at their feet and beg for charity, then cry when they receive no crumbs from the divine table, on the other hand..."
"'Never abandons,' {name}? Never abandons?! You only think that because he has not abandoned you yet!"
"No, {name}, no... You do not know of what you speak! I fear for your soul. What if your faithless words result in you spending eternity wandering the {g|Boneyard}Boneyard{/g}?"
